Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC: Collaborative Research: Center for Arthropod Management Technologies (CAMTech)
Award.AbstractNarration:
1338775 Iowa State University; Byrony Bonning
13387667 University of Kentucky; Subba Palli

The proposed Center for Arthropod Management Technologies (CAMTech) will streamline and link the efforts of industry and academia toward effective management of arthropod and nematode pests through a formalized and extended research partnership. The research efforts will be anchored by Iowa State University (ISU) as the lead institution, partnered with the University of Kentucky (UKY).

The proposed Center comprised of Iowa State University and the University of Kentucky will serve as an incubator for novel technologies. CAMTech will provide the basic research foundation necessary for the applied research goals of industry and will extend the utility of current arthropod management practices. The goals of CAMTech will be to (i) conduct pre-competitive research and transfer knowledge to industrial partners for in house development, (ii) optimize and extend the versatility of current technologies, and (iii) train undergraduate and graduate students as well as postdoctoral scholars for potential future employment within industry. An interdisciplinary team has been assembled with UKY researchers extending and complementing the skills and expertise of ISU researchers.

Establishment of this Center will enable a cohesive industry-university alliance that will allow industry to communicate their needs to academia toward a common goal, and to facilitate collaboration amongst companies. The diverse team of researchers will provide knowledge of fundamental systems relevant to arthropod management, allowing Center members to derive value from fundamental research and to expand the utility of current approaches. Students and postdoctoral researchers within the proposed Center will receive outstanding professional development training at both ISU and UKY. The commitment of ISU and UK to develop the academic potential of underrepresented groups in STEM fields will be further enhanced by informal mentorships, internships and career options with CAMTech industrial partners.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The development of new pest management methods is crucial for production of sufficient food for the increasing human population, and prevention of arthropod-transmitted disease to plants and humans. The widespread pest distribution associated with changing climatic conditions exacerbates the need for new pest management methods. The economic losses associated with the activities of arthropods and nematodes are a significant burden to society through both agricultural losses and human health costs. The Center for Arthropod Management Technologies (CAMTech) addresses issues that limit effective management of the major insect and nematode pests that impact agriculture and human health. Research conducted at the University of Kentucky (UK) CAMTech site addressed mechanisms of RNA interference (RNAi), the sub-lethal effect of neurotoxic insecticides on insect behavior, insecticide resistance, mechanisms of diapause and methods development. CAMTech funded 21 research projects during years 1–5 of Phase I with from 5 to 15 projects running in any given year. These included interdisciplinary collaborations across departments including the Department of Chemical and Materials Engineering. Five graduate students (two women) and eight post-doctoral fellows (one woman) were trained. One graduate and One postdoctoral researcher from the UK site now work within the industry. A total of seven papers have been published during Phase I from UK site with an additional six manuscripts in preparation.  Eight presentations were given by CAMTech researchers at national and international conferences. A survey conducted during the spring of 2017 highlighted the multiple benefits and significant impacts of CAMTech on members in terms of increased R&D efficiencies, improved processes, cost savings, changes in thinking and approach. The research products were transferred to member companies through quarterly reports and presentations at bi-annual IAB meetings and to the public in the form of publications and presentations at conferences. Fundamental knowledge gained from center research on mechanisms of RNA interference, insecticide resistance, toxicological effects of insecticides, physiological processes of pests and disease vectors facilitated R&D efforts of industry and expedited the development of new products for pest and disease vector control. The broader impacts form the UK site include research products that help in the development of novel pest management methods and training future workforce. REU supplement provided research experience to two undergraduate students (one minority and one woman).

 


Last Modified: 03/20/2019
Modified by: Subba R Palli
